Mistakes All Programmers Make

Apr 8, 2017 - 12:13 -- Erik Hallmark

Programming is a pretty complicated subject, and it's easy to make mistakes, we all do it from time to time, and if you're new to programming, you're going to make a lot of them. One of the best was to minimize the number of mistakes you make is to just know what the most common mistakes are. I'll take you through some of the most common mistakes I see in my code, and other peoples.

1. Not understanding the difference between value and reference types

The difference between reference and value types is a pretty crucial concept in programming, if you're not familiar with how they work, I'd suggest you spend some time doing research on them.

1. Less code means faster code... right?

This seems to be a pretty common misconception, but now, just because there are less lines of code in your program doesn't mean it will run faster. Most modern programming languages have something that's often referred to as "Syntactic sugar", which is something where code is made smaller or easier to read by having small bits of code that the compiler reads as larger blocks of code. These things can be very mundane, such as the var keyword in C# which will just makes the code easier to read, and will have no performance impact on the code. C# also contains another bit of syntactic sugar called the foreach loop, this is a very useful tool, as long as you when to use it, and whennot to use it, I often see people using foreach loops to iterate through a standard array, when it would be far more effiecent to iterate with a standard for loop.
